5.title: Juneteenth Challenges A Narrative About America’s History
5.subtitle: Juneteenth marks the day in 1865 when Union troops arrived in Galveston, Texas, and the enslaved people living there learned of their freedom — more than two years after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation. As such, the day tells a broader story of how emancipation was woefully delayed for Black people enslaved deep in the Confederacy.

6.title: How we're priming some kids for college — and others for prison
6.subtitle: In the United States, two institutions guide teenagers on the journey to adulthood: college and prison. Sociologist Alice Goffman spent six years in a troubled Philadelphia neighborhood and saw first-hand how teenagers of African-American and Latino backgrounds are funneled down the path to prison — sometimes starting with relatively minor infractions. In an impassioned talk she asks, "Why are we offering only handcuffs and jail time?"

6.title: Can the Beauty Industry Confront Colorism?
6.subtitle: The beauty industry has been trying to productively confront racism. Can it do the same with colorism, where lighter-skinned models are favored over those with darker skin?

7.title: Black Lives Matter
7.subtitle: We appreciate your support of the movement and our ongoing fight to end state-sanctioned violence, liberate Black people, and end white supremacy forever.

7.title: Knock Your Socks Off
7.subtitle: Created from an appreciation for high-quality socks that make a lasting impression and backed by years of retail buying experience, Knock Your Socks Off (aka KYSO) was founded in 2016 in Toronto, Canada.

products.name: Above the Clouds Women's Ankle Socks

8.title: Big Mama's Sauce
8.subtitle: We believe that to be the best we must use only the best ingredients. This homemade recipe has been the highlight of our family gatherings since at least 2002…honestly Big Mama can’t even remember, that’s how long she been making it! Big Mama never liked store bought sauce and she wanted to serve only the best to her loved ones. So here we are…on the store shelf ironically! Lol…We hope you taste only love and enjoy just as our family has for all of these years!

9.subtitle: With a perspective that is at once scientific, investigative, and informed by personal experience, Dr. Jennifer Eberhardt offers us the language and courage we need to face one of the biggest and most troubling issues of our time.

11.title: Seeing White Podcast Series
11.subtitle: Just what is going on with white people? Police shootings of unarmed African Americans. Acts of domestic terrorism by white supremacists. The renewed embrace of raw, undisguised white-identity politics. Unending racial inequity in schools, housing, criminal justice, and hiring. Some of this feels new, but in truth it’s an old story.

products.name: Princess Omalie Doll – Gala Edition
products.description: Princess Omalie comes from a royal lineage of beautiful elegant women and embodies the kindness, confidence and excitement of young girls today. In this Gala Edition, she is exquisitely dressed and coiffed.

products.name: Princess Omalie Doll – Coronation Edition
products.description: Princess Omalie comes from a royal lineage of beautiful elegant women and embodies the kindness, confidence and excitement of young girls today. In this Coronation Edition, she is exquisitely dressed and coifed in a rich, soft cape and a smooth silky costume, designed by "Atelier de Babazongo" – dressmakers of the Royal family. As a treat, she holds a special key as your invitation to unlock the magic of her kingdom.

products.name: Princess Omalie, The Coronation And The Polka Dot Lamb
products.description: Princess Omalie of the African kingdom of IgboOrai could be the happiest girl on the planet — except that her family has been under a curse. Unless the curse of the Goliath beetle necklace is lifted, Omalie’s father might die in a horrible freak accident. He might never be crowned king. Omalie worries about her family, and about her own safety; how will she ever lead a peaceful happy life, have friends, and go to school?

15.title: 360 Magazine
15.subtitle:
360 is an edgy fashion, lifestyle and culture magazine. We will introduce cutting-edge brands, entities and trends to tastemakers within their respective communities. Our founding members have over 30 years of collective experience both as notable talent and uber professionals within the realm of fashion, music, art, design and entertainment. We are more than just a magazine comprised of journalists, representing a movement of social awareness and change.

We are a LGBTQIA friendly publication. The magazine is contemporary in look and appeal. Quality art content is the constant goal. The magazine will be entertaining, newsworthy and thought-provoking. It will appeal to a broad entertainment readership. No magazine like it is available today, constantly celebrating racial and sexual ambiguous talent and artists.

16.subtitle: John Oliver discusses the importance of Black hair, the ways it can be a target of discrimination, and some ideas to address that.

16.subtitle: They view the success of black students as central to the success of their own teaching. Read more from Pirette McKamey, principal of San Francisco’s Mission High School and an anti-racist educator for more than 30 years.

17.title: White Fragility: Why It's So Hard for White People to Talk About Racism
17.subtitle: This book explicates the dynamics of White Fragility and how we might build our capacity in the on-going work towards racial justice.

17.title: What Happened in Kenosha, WI?
17.subtitle: Cellphone video of the incident shows police officers in Kenosha, Wisconsin shooting a Black man multiple times on August 23 as he tried to get into a vehicle. Read more about the incident and the protests that followed here.

18.title: How students of color confront impostor syndrome
18.subtitle: As a black woman from a tough part of the Bronx who grew up to attain all the markers of academic prestige, Dena Simmons knows that for students of color, success in school sometimes comes at the cost of living authentically. Now an educator herself, Simmons discusses how we might create a classroom that makes all students feel proud of who they are.

20.title: How to deconstruct racism, one headline at a time
20.subtitle: Baratunde Thurston explores the phenomenon of white Americans calling the police on black Americans who have committed the crimes of ... eating, walking or generally "living while black." In this profound, thought-provoking and often hilarious talk, he reveals the power of language to change stories of trauma into stories of healing — while challenging us all to level up.

21.title: How colorism shapes our standards of beauty
21.subtitle: When Chika Okoro read the casting call for one of her favorite films, she noticed that actresses with darker skin were assigned lesser roles — prompting her to address a phenomenon she'd experienced all her life: colorism. In this eye-opening talk, Okoro shares coping strategies along with steps that could help eliminate this insidious and destructive mindset of discrimination.

26.title: Open Yale Courses: African American History: From Emancipation to the Present
26.subtitle: The purpose of this course is to examine the African American experience in the United States from 1863 to the present. Prominent themes include the end of the Civil War and the beginning of Reconstruction; African Americans’ urbanization experiences; the development of the modern civil rights movement and its aftermath; and the thought and leadership of Booker T. Washington, Ida B. Wells-Barnett, W.E.B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King Jr., and Malcolm X.

26.title: Red Bay Coffee
26.subtitle: Red Bay Coffee is at the forefront of what we believe is the fourth wave of coffee—a firm commitment to ensure coffee production is not only high quality and sustainable, but a vehicle for diversity, inclusion, social and economic restoration, entrepreneurship, and environmental sustainability. We are foodies, artists, activists, community folk, and innovators who love, love, love what we do.

27.title: Book: Understanding Mass Incarceration
27.subtitle: A People's Guide to the Key Civil Rights Struggle of Our Time

27.title: 3 ways to speak English
27.subtitle: Jamila Lyiscott is a "tri-tongued orator" in her powerful spoken-word essay "Broken English," she celebrates — and challenges — the three distinct flavors of English she speaks with her friends, in the classroom and with her parents. As she explores the complicated history and present-day identity that each language represents, she unpacks what it means to be "articulate."

29.title: Four-year Analysis: Police-related deaths across racial groups
29.subtitle: A four-year research study released on June 24th, 2020 shows that Black Americans were, on average, more than three times as likely as White Americans to be killed during a police encounter.

29.title: Covid-19’s Impact on People in Prison
29.subtitle: People who are incarcerated are at great risk of sickness and death as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic and more must be done to release people who are imprisoned and are not a threat to public safety or are elderly or infirm.

30.title: How studying privilege systems can strengthen compassion
30.subtitle: Her TED Talk offers a shift in the traditional view of race, equity and privilege. McIntosh uses her own experience as a white woman to inform her own knowledge of racial experiences from a white perspective.

30.title: AcARRE
30.subtitle: AcARRE™ is a natural prestige brand of multi-use bioactive beauty products for the beauty minimalist to age beautifully, based on modernized African and Pacific Islander ancestry elements delivering multi-level benefits, bringing balance to the skin.

31.title: Code Switch Podcast
31.subtitle: Hosted by journalists of color, our podcast tackles the subject of race head-on. We explore how it impacts every part of society — from politics and pop culture to history, sports and everything in between. This podcast makes ALL OF US part of the conversation — because we're all part of the story.

31.title: Intersectionality Matters! Podcast
31.subtitle: Intersectionality Matters! is a podcast hosted by Kimberlé Crenshaw, an American civil rights advocate and a leading scholar of critical race theory.
